Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat buzzing with messages from my stepmother. “Don’t forget, we’re lighting the candles at 6 sharp. It’s important to your dad.” My heart squeezed. Ever since I became part of this family, I’d tried to show I cared about their traditions, even if they still felt foreign to me. Tonight’s holiday gathering was supposed to be my chance to prove I belonged.

But my other phone vibrated—dispatch reminding me about the mandatory pre-shift briefing. New operational procedures, no exceptions. As a subway operator, I knew the rules: miss a briefing, risk suspension. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind, “We count on you to keep the system safe and running.”

I glanced at the clock. The briefing started in ten minutes, the same time my family would be gathering in the living room, waiting for me to light the candles. My stepmother’s hopeful face flashed in my mind, but so did the stern look of my supervisor. I felt torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down on me, unsure which expectation I could bear to disappoint.
